segment.source: Provides a means to specify the source of a binding in terms of a relative relationship in the run-time object graph.
segment.target: Provides a means to specify the source of a binding in terms of a relative relationship in the run-time object graph.

segment.source: {RelativeSource} markup extension
segment.target: {RelativeSource} markup extension

segment.source: {RelativeSource} markup extension
segment.target: {RelativeSource} markup extension

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Provides a means to specify the source of a binding in terms of a relative relationship in the run-time object graph.
segment.target: Provides a means to specify the source of a binding in terms of a relative relationship in the run-time object graph.

segment.source: XAML attribute usage (Self mode)
segment.target: XAML attribute usage (Self mode)

segment.source: XAML attribute usage (TemplatedParent mode)
segment.target: XAML attribute usage (TemplatedParent mode)

segment.source: XAML values
segment.target: XAML values

segment.source: | Term | Description | | {RelativeSource Self} | Produces a Mode value is Self.
segment.target: | Term | Description | | {RelativeSource Self} | Produces a Mode value is Self.

segment.source: The target element should be used as the source for this binding.
segment.target: The target element should be used as the source for this binding.

segment.source: This is useful for binding one property of an element to another property on the same element.
segment.target: This is useful for binding one property of an element to another property on the same element.

segment.source: | | {RelativeSource TemplatedParent} | Produces a ControlTemplate is applied is the source for this binding.
segment.target: | | {RelativeSource TemplatedParent} | Produces a ControlTemplate is applied is the source for this binding.

segment.source: This is useful for applying runtime information to bindings at the template level.
segment.target: This is useful for applying runtime information to bindings at the template level.

segment.source: Remarks
segment.target: Remarks

segment.source: A Binding can set Binding.RelativeSource either as an attribute on a Binding object element or as a component within a {Binding} markup extension.
segment.target: A Binding can set Binding.RelativeSource either as an attribute on a Binding object element or as a component within a {Binding} markup extension.

segment.source: This is why two different XAML syntaxes are shown.
segment.target: This is why two different XAML syntaxes are shown.

segment.source: RelativeSource is similar to {Binding} markup extension in that it is a markup extension that is capable of returning instances of itself, supporting a string-based construction that essentially passes an argument to the constructor.
segment.target: RelativeSource is similar to {Binding} markup extension in that it is a markup extension that is capable of returning instances of itself, supporting a string-based construction that essentially passes an argument to the constructor.

segment.source: In this case, the argument being passed is the Mode value.
segment.target: In this case, the argument being passed is the Mode value.

segment.source: The Self mode is useful for cases where the same element should be used as the source object and target object for a binding, but different properties are the source and the target.
segment.target: The Self mode is useful for cases where the same element should be used as the source object and target object for a binding, but different properties are the source and the target.

segment.source: This is useful for binding one property of an element to another property on the same element, and is a variation on ElementName binding that does not require naming and then self-referencing the element.
segment.target: This is useful for binding one property of an element to another property on the same element, and is a variation on ElementName binding that does not require naming and then self-referencing the element.

segment.source: If you bind one property of an element to another property on the same element, either the properties must use the same property type, or you must also use a Converter on the binding to convert the values.
segment.target: If you bind one property of an element to another property on the same element, either the properties must use the same property type, or you must also use a Converter on the binding to convert the values.

segment.source: For example, you could use Height as a source for Width without conversion, but you'd need a converter to use IsEnabled as a source for Visibility.
segment.target: For example, you could use Height as a source for Width without conversion, but you'd need a converter to use IsEnabled as a source for Visibility.

segment.source: Here's an example.
segment.target: Here's an example.

segment.source: This Rectangle uses a {Binding} markup extension so that its Height and Width are always equal and it renders as a square.
segment.target: This Rectangle uses a {Binding} markup extension so that its Height and Width are always equal and it renders as a square.

segment.source: Only the Height is set as a fixed value.
segment.target: Only the Height is set as a fixed value.

segment.source: For this Rectangle its default DataContext is null, not this.
segment.target: For this Rectangle its default DataContext is null, not this.

segment.source: So to establish the data context source to be the object itself (and enable binding to its other properties) we use the argument in the {Binding} markup extension usage.
segment.target: So to establish the data context source to be the object itself (and enable binding to its other properties) we use the argument in the {Binding} markup extension usage.

segment.source: Another technique that can be useful is to use as a way to set an object's DataContext to itself, where the Page class has been extended with a custom property that's already providing a ready-to-go view model for its own data binding.
segment.target: Another technique that can be useful is to use as a way to set an object's DataContext to itself, where the Page class has been extended with a custom property that's already providing a ready-to-go view model for its own data binding.

segment.source: You see this technique in some of the SDK examples:
segment.target: You see this technique in some of the SDK examples:

segment.source: Note The XAML usage for RelativeSource shows only the usage for which it is intended: setting a value for Binding.RelativeSource in XAML as part of a binding expression.
segment.target: Note The XAML usage for RelativeSource shows only the usage for which it is intended: setting a value for Binding.RelativeSource in XAML as part of a binding expression.

segment.source: Theoretically, other usages are possible if setting a property where the value is RelativeSource.
segment.target: Theoretically, other usages are possible if setting a property where the value is RelativeSource.
